title: Projects
text:
Research Publications

One Health in Social-Ecological Systems: Optimizing Natural Resources, Livelihoods and Health of Humans and Animals in Mongolia
Status: Under revision | Role: Co-author, Annex Development
This interdisciplinary research explores the complex relationships between human communities, livestock, wildlife, and environmental health in Mongolia‚Äôs pastoral systems. My contribution focused on developing comprehensive annexes that bridge veterinary science with socio-ecological analysis.
Key Contributions:

Development of technical annexes linking animal health indicators to ecosystem sustainability
Integration of veterinary epidemiological concepts with social-ecological frameworks
Synthesis of livestock health data with environmental and livelihood outcomes

Current Research



Master‚Äôs Thesis: Environmental and Anthropogenic Factors for Tick-borne Diseases in Switzerland
Status: Protocol development phase | Expected completion: 2026
Investigating how climate change and human activities influence the distribution and risk patterns of tick-borne diseases across Swiss landscapes.
Methodology:

Time series analysis using national surveillance data
Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for spatial analysis
Integration of environmental, demographic, and epidemiological datasets
Statistical modeling to identify risk factors and predict future trends

Data Sources: Swiss national health surveillance systems and meteorological data

title: Projects
text:
Technical Projects

Mathematical Modeling of Influenza Epidemics
Tools: R, SEIR models, epidemiological modeling
Developed comprehensive mathematical models to simulate influenza transmission dynamics, combining SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) frameworks with additional epidemiological parameters.
Technical Skills Demonstrated:

Advanced R programming for epidemiological modeling
Parameter estimation and model validation
Scenario analysis and sensitivity testing
Data visualization of epidemic curves and transmission patterns



Research Data Management & Analysis
Tools: R, data cleaning, statistical analysis
Comprehensive data cleaning and analysis project focusing on research data management best practices. Demonstrate proficiency in:

Data quality assessment and cleaning protocols
Statistical analysis pipeline development
Documentation and reproducible analysis workflows
Data visualization and reporting

title: Projects
text:
Innovation in Development

VetNota: AI Assistant
Status: In development | Target: Mexican veterinary market
Developing an AI powered mobile application to revolutionize veterinary consultations by reducing administrative burden and improving clinical documentation accuracy.
Key Features:

Audio-to-text transcription of veterinary consultations
Automated consultation summaries with key clinical findings
Diagnostic suggestions based on clinical protocols
Streamlined medical records management
Time optimization for veterinary professionals

Technical Stack: Mobile app development, natural language processing, veterinary clinical databases

title: Projects
text:
Skills Demonstrated Across Projects

Programming: R, statistical modeling, data visualization
Analysis: Time series analysis, GIS, epidemiological modeling
Research: Literature review, protocol development, interdisciplinary collaboration
Innovation: Mobile app development, AI integration, user experience design
Communication: Scientific writing, technical documentation, cross-cultural collaboration

title: About
text:
My journey began in veterinary school in Mexico, vaccinating cats and dogs against rabies in both rural and urban areas. This experience led me to pursue a postgraduate in epidemiology.



Following real time reports from WAHIS and publications from the World Organisation for Animal Health introduced me to disease surveillance and the One Health approach.



Working as a vet across Mexico and the USA taught me something crucial: context matters. The same disease behaves differently depending on culture, economy, and environment. Numbers tell part of the story, but the human and animal experiences behind the data are just as important.



I learned that prevention and monitoring are essential, and that small agents can cause large scale consequences, as the COVID-19 pandemic showed.



Now, while researching tick-borne diseases and hiking in the Swiss Alps, I focus on how environment and human behavior shape disease patterns.

My journey began in veterinary school in Mexico, vaccinating cats and dogs against rabies in both rural and urban areas. This experience led me to pursue a postgraduate in epidemiology.



Following real time reports from WAHIS and publications from the World Organisation for Animal Health introduced me to disease surveillance and the One Health approach.



Working as a vet across Mexico and the USA taught me something crucial: context matters. The same disease behaves differently depending on culture, economy, and environment. Numbers tell part of the story, but the human and animal experiences behind the data are just as important.



I learned that prevention and monitoring are essential, and that small agents can cause large scale consequences, as the COVID-19 pandemic showed.



Now, while researching tick-borne diseases and hiking in the Swiss Alps, I focus on how environment and human behavior shape disease patterns.

title: About
text:
Beyond the Lab

Hiking
I grew up hiking in the mountains of central Mexico, my hometown is a national park, and I grew up respecting nature and wanting to help protect it.


Mountain Biking
I enjoy the adrenaline of outdoor sports, and learning mountain biking has taught me resilience.


Lifelong Learning
I genuinely enjoy learning new things and being a beginner. There‚Äôs something exciting about figuring things out from scratch, whether it‚Äôs crocheting, baking, learning programming language, or a new statistical method. I think this curiosity and comfort with not knowing everything is essential in a field like epidemiology, where we‚Äôre constantly encountering new challenges and evolving threats.
